<ce:figure id="f0005">

<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">The molecular structure of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L is arranged with atom numberings. Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 1

The molecular structure of H2L is arranged with atom numberings. Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.

<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">(a) The coordination environments of Y1 in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and (b) distorted tricapped trigonal prismatic coordination environment of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (hydrogen atoms and uncoordinated water molecules were omitted for clarity).</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 2

(a) The coordination environments of Y1 in complex 1 and (b) distorted tricapped trigonal prismatic coordination environment of complex 1 (hydrogen atoms and uncoordinated water molecules were omitted for clarity).

</ce:caption>

</ce:caption>

</ce:figure>

(1) Images of as-prepared complex 1 and its’ single crystal photo; (2) images of dehydrated products of complex 1 and its’ amorphous solid photo; (3) images of rehydrated products of complex 1 and its’ single crystal picture; (4) PXRD patterns: (a) simulated pattern of complex 1; (b) as-prepared complex 1; (c) dehydrated products of complex 1; and (d) rehydrated products of complex 1.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0060" view="all">Two novel inorganic–organic 3D network, namely{[<ce:italic>Ln</ce:italic>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> [<ce:italic>Ln</ce:italic>=Y (1), Ce (2)] [<ce:italic>Ln</ce:italic>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O [<ce:italic>Ln</ce:italic>=Y (1), Ce (2)], have been prepared through the assembly of the ligand 1,2-bis[3-(1,2,4-triazolyl)-4-amino-5-carboxylmethylthio]ethane (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L) and lanthanide (III) salts under hydrothermal condition and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffractions. In complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions adopt three different coordination fashions (bidentate chelate, bidentate bridging and bidentate chelate bridging) connecting <ce:italic>Ln</ce:italic>(III) ions via the oxygen atoms from carboxylate moieties. Both 1 and 2 exhibit 3D network structures with 2-fold interpenetration. Interestingly, the reversible desorption–adsorption behavior of lattice water is significantly observed in the two compounds. The result shows their potential application as late-model water absorbent in the field of adsorption material.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
Two novel inorganic–organic 3D network, namely{[Ln(L)1.5(H2O)2]·5H2O}n [Ln=Y (1), Ce (2)] [Ln(L)1.5(H2O)2]·5H2O [Ln=Y (1), Ce (2)], have been prepared through the assembly of the ligand 1,2-bis[3-(1,2,4-triazolyl)-4-amino-5-carboxylmethylthio]ethane (H2L) and lanthanide (III) salts under hydrothermal condition and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffractions. In complexes 1 and 2, the L2− anions adopt three different coordination fashions (bidentate chelate, bidentate bridging and bidentate chelate bridging) connecting Ln(III) ions via the oxygen atoms from carboxylate moieties. Both 1 and 2 exhibit 3D network structures with 2-fold interpenetration. Interestingly, the reversible desorption–adsorption behavior of lattice water is significantly observed in the two compounds. The result shows their potential application as late-model water absorbent in the field of adsorption material.

Graphical abstract
Two inorganic–organic 3D network, namely {[Ln(L)1.5(H2O)2]·5H2O}n [Ln=Y (1), Ce (2)], have been prepared under hydrothermal condition and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffractions. Both 1 and 2 exhibit 3D network structures with 2-fold interpenetration. Interestingly, the reversible desorption–adsorption behavior of lattice water is significantly observed in the two compounds. The result shows their potential application as late-model water absorbent in the field of adsorption material.

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Exploring highly symmetrical ligands and suitable metal salts to construct supramolecular architectures has attracted much interest . Lanthanide coordination frameworks are of great importance currently, not only because of their fascinating architectures but also for their technological applications, such as diagnostic tools, luminescence sensors, absorption, and host–guest chemistry . An effective and facile approach in building such networks is to select or design appropriate organic bridging ligands that can bind metal ions in different modes and provide a possible route to achieve more intriguing polymeric structures . Carboxylate ligands can be an excellent candidate in supramolecular assembly as a result of its versatile coordination modes . So far, great efforts have been devoted to construct the polymers of rare earth (III) salts with rigid aromatic ligands, such as 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate , imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate  and so on. The studies on the metal coordination polymers of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L in our lab have conﬁrmed that H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L is a good building block based on its various conformation and coordination modes . The successful syntheses of these complexes prompted us to further investigate the syntheses and application of lanthanide coordination polymers. Recently, several rare earth polymers with the flexible ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>tzda [H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>tzda=(1,3,4-thiadiazole-2,5-diyldithio)diacetic acid] have been reported by Wang et al. . However, complexes with flexible ligand containing carboxylate groups, which exhibit 2-fold interpenetration with intriguing 1D channels, are relatively scarce. In contrast to the rigid ligands, the flexible ones exhibit more conformational and coordination versatility. Furthermore, the resulting structures can be controlled and adjusted through changing their conformation and coordination modes . At present, most of the studies on the complexes have been only confined to description of their synthesis and structure, however, the studies on the application of these complexes as function materials have not drawn enough attention.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
Exploring highly symmetrical ligands and suitable metal salts to construct supramolecular architectures has attracted much interest . Lanthanide coordination frameworks are of great importance currently, not only because of their fascinating architectures but also for their technological applications, such as diagnostic tools, luminescence sensors, absorption, and host–guest chemistry . An effective and facile approach in building such networks is to select or design appropriate organic bridging ligands that can bind metal ions in different modes and provide a possible route to achieve more intriguing polymeric structures . Carboxylate ligands can be an excellent candidate in supramolecular assembly as a result of its versatile coordination modes . So far, great efforts have been devoted to construct the polymers of rare earth (III) salts with rigid aromatic ligands, such as 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate , imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate  and so on. The studies on the metal coordination polymers of H2L in our lab have conﬁrmed that H2L is a good building block based on its various conformation and coordination modes . The successful syntheses of these complexes prompted us to further investigate the syntheses and application of lanthanide coordination polymers. Recently, several rare earth polymers with the flexible ligand H2tzda [H2tzda=(1,3,4-thiadiazole-2,5-diyldithio)diacetic acid] have been reported by Wang et al. . However, complexes with flexible ligand containing carboxylate groups, which exhibit 2-fold interpenetration with intriguing 1D channels, are relatively scarce. In contrast to the rigid ligands, the flexible ones exhibit more conformational and coordination versatility. Furthermore, the resulting structures can be controlled and adjusted through changing their conformation and coordination modes . At present, most of the studies on the complexes have been only confined to description of their synthesis and structure, however, the studies on the application of these complexes as function materials have not drawn enough attention.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Based on above backgrounds, our research interest currently focuses on the construction of novel lanthanide coordination frameworks using the ligand containing carboxylate groups, as well as their application performance in the field of function material. In the present work, the assembly of the ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L [H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L=1,2-bis[3-(1,2,4-triazolyl)-4-amino-5-carboxylmethylthio] ethane with lanthanide (III) salts under hydrothermal condition has lead to two coordination polymers with 3D network {[<ce:italic>Ln</ce:italic>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> [<ce:italic>Ln</ce:italic>=Y(<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), Ce(<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)] containing 2-fold interpenetration. In addition, the reversible desorption–adsorption behavior of lattice water is interestingly found in the two complexes, which is significant because of their potential application as adsorption material in the future.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Based on above backgrounds, our research interest currently focuses on the construction of novel lanthanide coordination frameworks using the ligand containing carboxylate groups, as well as their application performance in the field of function material. In the present work, the assembly of the ligand H2L [H2L=1,2-bis[3-(1,2,4-triazolyl)-4-amino-5-carboxylmethylthio] ethane with lanthanide (III) salts under hydrothermal condition has lead to two coordination polymers with 3D network {[Ln(L)1.5(H2O)2]·5H2O}n [Ln=Y(1), Ce(2)] containing 2-fold interpenetration. In addition, the reversible desorption–adsorption behavior of lattice water is interestingly found in the two complexes, which is significant because of their potential application as adsorption material in the future.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental section</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials and measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">All chemicals from commercial sources were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Carlo-Erba 1160 Elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded in the region of 4000–400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup> on a Nicolet NEXUS 470-FTIR Spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets. UV–Vis absorption spectra in the solid state were taken using a Cary 5000 UV–Vis–NIR spectrophotometer. Themogravimetric analyses were carried out with a NETZSCH STA 409 unit at a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min under air atmosphere.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental section
Materials and measurements
All chemicals from commercial sources were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Carlo-Erba 1160 Elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded in the region of 4000–400cm–1 on a Nicolet NEXUS 470-FTIR Spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets. UV–Vis absorption spectra in the solid state were taken using a Cary 5000 UV–Vis–NIR spectrophotometer. Themogravimetric analyses were carried out with a NETZSCH STA 409 unit at a heating rate of 10°C/min under air atmosphere.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">1,2-bis[3-(1,2,4-triazolyl)-4-amino-5-mercapto]ethane as starting material was prepared according to the reported procedure . The ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L was synthesized as follows: (1.89<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.02<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol) chloroacetic acid, 1,2-bis[3-(1,2,4-triazolyl)-4-amino-5-mercapto]ethane (2.58<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.01<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol), sodium carbonate (3.12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.02<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol), 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml water, and refluxed for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h under stirring. The mixture was then cooled to room temperature and concentrated hydrochloric acid was introduced with stirring until pH=2. The precipitate was filtered off and washed with water, giving a fine white powder in 64% yield (2.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g). m.p. 186–187<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Anal. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (%): C, 32.05; H, 3.74; N, 29.91. Found (%): C, 31.98; H, 3.78; N, 29.94. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3354 (w), 3206 (w), 2930 (w), 1707 (s), 1632 (w), 1428 (m), 1374 (s), 1309 (m), 1229 (m), 1186 (m), 912 (w), 674 (w). 649(w). <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>HNMR (400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MHz, DMSO): <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic>=3.838(s,4H), 3.092(t,4H), 2.075(s,6H); <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C NMR (400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MHz), DMSO): <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic>=21.54, 31.14, 151.68, 155.79, 170.27<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of H2L
1,2-bis[3-(1,2,4-triazolyl)-4-amino-5-mercapto]ethane as starting material was prepared according to the reported procedure . The ligand H2L was synthesized as follows: (1.89g, 0.02mol) chloroacetic acid, 1,2-bis[3-(1,2,4-triazolyl)-4-amino-5-mercapto]ethane (2.58g, 0.01mol), sodium carbonate (3.12g, 0.02mol), 50ml water, and refluxed for 3h under stirring. The mixture was then cooled to room temperature and concentrated hydrochloric acid was introduced with stirring until pH=2. The precipitate was filtered off and washed with water, giving a fine white powder in 64% yield (2.4g). m.p. 186–187°C. Anal. Calc. for C10H14N8O4S2 (%): C, 32.05; H, 3.74; N, 29.91. Found (%): C, 31.98; H, 3.78; N, 29.94. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3354 (w), 3206 (w), 2930 (w), 1707 (s), 1632 (w), 1428 (m), 1374 (s), 1309 (m), 1229 (m), 1186 (m), 912 (w), 674 (w). 649(w). 1HNMR (400MHz, DMSO): δ=3.838(s,4H), 3.092(t,4H), 2.075(s,6H); 13C NMR (400MHz), DMSO): δ=21.54, 31.14, 151.68, 155.79, 170.27ppm.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Preparation of {[Y(L)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> (1)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is synthesized by the hydrothermal reaction of Y(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 274.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg), H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 374<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg), NaOH (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg) and deionized water (14<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) in a sealed Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) at 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 7 days. After being cooled to room temperature, crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (colorless, block-like) were collected by filtration. Yield: 48% based on Y. Anal. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>YN<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>): C, 23.27; H, 4.14; N, 21.72%. Found: C, 23.21; H, 4.18; N, 21.68%. IR data (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3326(m), 1618(w), 1586(s), 1435(s), 1405(s), 1238(m),1029(m), 941(w), 908(w), 777(w), 685(m).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of {[Y(L)1.5(H2O)2]·5H2O}n (1)
Polymer 1 is synthesized by the hydrothermal reaction of Y(NO3)3·6H2O (1mmol, 274.9mg), H2L (1mmol, 374mg), NaOH (2mmol, 80mg) and deionized water (14ml) in a sealed Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (25ml) at 120°C for 7 days. After being cooled to room temperature, crystals of 1 (colorless, block-like) were collected by filtration. Yield: 48% based on Y. Anal. Calc. for C15H32YN12O13S3 (1): C, 23.27; H, 4.14; N, 21.72%. Found: C, 23.21; H, 4.18; N, 21.68%. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3326(m), 1618(w), 1586(s), 1435(s), 1405(s), 1238(m),1029(m), 941(w), 908(w), 777(w), 685(m).

Yield: 51% based on Ce. Anal. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>CeN<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>): C, 21.51; H, 3.82; N, 20.08%. Found: C, 21.48; H, 3.85; N, 20.13%. IR data (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3328(m), 1621(w), 1584(s), 1436(s), 1406(s), 1236(m),1029(m), 942(w), 908(w), 777(w), 685(m).</ce:para>

Preparation of {[Ce(L)1.5(H2O)2]·5H2O}n (2)
The synthesis of 2 was similar to that of 1, except Ce(NO3)3 was used instead of Y(NO3)3 and the reaction time were 5 days. Yield: 51% based on Ce. Anal. Calc. for C15H32CeN12O13S3 (2): C, 21.51; H, 3.82; N, 20.08%. Found: C, 21.48; H, 3.85; N, 20.13%. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3328(m), 1621(w), 1584(s), 1436(s), 1406(s), 1236(m),1029(m), 942(w), 908(w), 777(w), 685(m).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Single-crystal structure determination</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The intensity data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were collected at 293<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K on a Rigaku Saturn 724 CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>α radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). All of the structures were solved by direct methods and expanded using Fourier techniques. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms were assigned with common isotropic displacement factors and included in the final refinement by using geometrical constraints. The final cycle of full-matrix least squares refinement was based on the observed reflections and variable parameters. All calculations were performed using the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package . <ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>
 shows crystallographic data of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L and polymers <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Selected bond distances and angles for H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L and polymers <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are listed in <ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>
.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Single-crystal structure determination
The intensity data for 1 and 2 were collected at 293K on a Rigaku Saturn 724 CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ=0.71073Å). All of the structures were solved by direct methods and expanded using Fourier techniques. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms were assigned with common isotropic displacement factors and included in the final refinement by using geometrical constraints. The final cycle of full-matrix least squares refinement was based on the observed reflections and variable parameters. All calculations were performed using the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package . 
 shows crystallographic data of H2L and polymers 1 and 2. Selected bond distances and angles for H2L and polymers 1 and 2 are listed in 
.

<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Description of the crystal structures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">The crystal structure of the ligand (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L) is shown in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>
. The ligand crystallizes in the monoclinic system, space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that title polymers <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are isomorphous and isostructural. Hence, only the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> will be described in detail. Polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the triclinic system, space group <mml:math altimg="si0003.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mi>P</mml:mi>
<mml:mover accent="true">
<mml:mi mathvariant="normal">1</mml:mi>
<mml:mo mathvariant="normal">¯</mml:mo>
</mml:mover>
</mml:math>, and the asymmetric unit consists of one Y(III) cation, one and a half L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions and two water molecules. Y(III) is nine-coordinated and surrounded by seven oxygen atoms provided by five L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions (O1, O1A, O2A, O3, O4A, O5, O6) and two coordination water molecules (O7 and O8) to form a distorted tricapped trigonal prism as depicted in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>
. The Y–O distances range from 2.305(3) to 2.684(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and lie in the range of 2.234(3)–2.878(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å which are mostly found for nine-coordinated yttrium cations . In this compound, all carboxyl groups of the H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L are deprotonated, It should be noted that all the L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> employ three different types of coordination modes (bidentate chelate, bidentate bridging, bidentate chelate bridging) to construct subunits of [Y<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]. L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions with bidentate chelate bridging coordination modes link Y(III) centers to form a 1D zigzag chain in <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> direction. The second type of L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions with bidentate bridging coordination mode join Y(III) centers to form a 2D layer. The third type of L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions which adopt bidentate chelate bridging coordination mode, connect Y(III) centers to form a 3D network, as seen in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>
. Because the single 3D network has spacious voids, it allows one more identical network to interpenetrate giving rise to a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-polonium network. From a topological view, the formed 3D net of the title polymers can be best described as a doubly interpenetrated six-connected net with the Schläfli symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>), as illustrated in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>
, when the [Y<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] centers are treated as six-connected nodes while L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions as bridging linkers.</ce:para>

Results and discussion
Description of the crystal structures
The crystal structure of the ligand (H2L) is shown in 
. The ligand crystallizes in the monoclinic system, space group P21/c.
Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that title polymers 1 and 2 are isomorphous and isostructural. Hence, only the structure of 1 will be described in detail. Polymer 1 crystallizes in the triclinic system, space group 
P

1
¯

, and the asymmetric unit consists of one Y(III) cation, one and a half L2− anions and two water molecules. Y(III) is nine-coordinated and surrounded by seven oxygen atoms provided by five L2− anions (O1, O1A, O2A, O3, O4A, O5, O6) and two coordination water molecules (O7 and O8) to form a distorted tricapped trigonal prism as depicted in 
. The Y–O distances range from 2.305(3) to 2.684(3)Å and lie in the range of 2.234(3)–2.878(3)Å which are mostly found for nine-coordinated yttrium cations . In this compound, all carboxyl groups of the H2L are deprotonated, It should be noted that all the L2− anions in 1 employ three different types of coordination modes (bidentate chelate, bidentate bridging, bidentate chelate bridging) to construct subunits of [Y2(L)3(H2O)4]. L2− anions with bidentate chelate bridging coordination modes link Y(III) centers to form a 1D zigzag chain in c direction. The second type of L2− anions with bidentate bridging coordination mode join Y(III) centers to form a 2D layer. The third type of L2− anions which adopt bidentate chelate bridging coordination mode, connect Y(III) centers to form a 3D network, as seen in 
. Because the single 3D network has spacious voids, it allows one more identical network to interpenetrate giving rise to a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D a-polonium network. From a topological view, the formed 3D net of the title polymers can be best described as a doubly interpenetrated six-connected net with the Schläfli symbol of (412.64), as illustrated in 
, when the [Y2(L)3(H2O)4] centers are treated as six-connected nodes while L2− anions as bridging linkers.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Interestingly, in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the 3D framework consists of one-dimensional channels along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> direction, after the van der Waals radii of the surface atoms are removed, the free channel is sized ca. 12.172×18.117<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The channels are resided by uncoordinated water molecules (O9, O10, O11, O12, O13), as described in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>
. A series of hydrogen bonds are formed among the coordinated water molecules, the coordinated water and the triazole N atoms, the uncoordinated water and NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, respectively, which stabilize the 3D supramolecular architecture. Supposing the lattice water molecules are removed, the hydrogen bond system would be destroyed. For example, the dehydrated example of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a white non-transparent crystal instead of a single crystal form.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Interestingly, in 1, the 3D framework consists of one-dimensional channels along the b direction, after the van der Waals radii of the surface atoms are removed, the free channel is sized ca. 12.172×18.117Å. The channels are resided by uncoordinated water molecules (O9, O10, O11, O12, O13), as described in 
. A series of hydrogen bonds are formed among the coordinated water molecules, the coordinated water and the triazole N atoms, the uncoordinated water and NH2, respectively, which stabilize the 3D supramolecular architecture. Supposing the lattice water molecules are removed, the hydrogen bond system would be destroyed. For example, the dehydrated example of 1 exhibits a white non-transparent crystal instead of a single crystal form.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Spectra properties and thermogravimetric analyses</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The IR spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> show the characteristic absorptions of L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions. The absence of band in the region 1690–1730<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup> indicates the complete deprotonation of the–COOH. The asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration bands of–COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> groups appear at 1618, 1586 and 1405<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 1621, 1584 and 1406<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively, suggesting that–COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> functions in different coordination modes. The analyses of IR spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are in good agreement with crystal structures and charge balance considerations.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Spectra properties and thermogravimetric analyses
The IR spectra of 1 and 2 show the characteristic absorptions of L2− anions. The absence of band in the region 1690–1730cm–1 indicates the complete deprotonation of the–COOH. The asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration bands of–COO− groups appear at 1618, 1586 and 1405cm–1 for 1, 1621, 1584 and 1406cm–1 for 2, respectively, suggesting that–COO− functions in different coordination modes. The analyses of IR spectra of 1 and 2 are in good agreement with crystal structures and charge balance considerations.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The solid state UV–vis spectra of ligand and the corresponding complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are further determined (). The complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> give similar characteristic absorptions at approximately 240<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm in accord with the free ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L, which all may be attributed to the intraligand π→π⁎ transition of the ligand. The effective bands at approximately 240<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> indicate a slight blue-shift compared to free ligand, presumably due to reduction of the π electron density induced by the coordination of carboxylate group with metal ions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The solid state UV–vis spectra of ligand and the corresponding complexes 1 and 2 are further determined (). The complexes 1 and 2 give similar characteristic absorptions at approximately 240nm in accord with the free ligand H2L, which all may be attributed to the intraligand π→π⁎ transition of the ligand. The effective bands at approximately 240nm for complexes 1 and 2 indicate a slight blue-shift compared to free ligand, presumably due to reduction of the π electron density induced by the coordination of carboxylate group with metal ions.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Thermal stability was measured by TG analysis in air atmosphere. Two samples exhibit similar thermal decomposition behaviors in the range of ambient temperature to 890<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. They exhibit a good stability at air atmosphere and ambient temperature. The thermal decomposition process of both samples exhibits three main weight losses. The first weight loss of 12.3% happens between 30 and 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (calcd: 11.6%), which corresponds to the loss of five lattice water. The second loss ranges from 260 to 314<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, it can be assigned to the loss of the two coordinated water molecules accompanied by the initial breakdown of the organic moieties. Immediately following the third losses start at a temperature above 314<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C which corresponds to the combustion of the organic moieties, and do not end until 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, as demonstrated in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>
a. The final products are not characterized. TGA curve of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows similar thermal decomposition behaviors. The TGA curve exhibits an initial weight loss of 11.8% from 30 to 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (calcd: 10.9%) ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal stability was measured by TG analysis in air atmosphere. Two samples exhibit similar thermal decomposition behaviors in the range of ambient temperature to 890°C. They exhibit a good stability at air atmosphere and ambient temperature. The thermal decomposition process of both samples exhibits three main weight losses. The first weight loss of 12.3% happens between 30 and 160°C for 1 (calcd: 11.6%), which corresponds to the loss of five lattice water. The second loss ranges from 260 to 314°C, it can be assigned to the loss of the two coordinated water molecules accompanied by the initial breakdown of the organic moieties. Immediately following the third losses start at a temperature above 314°C which corresponds to the combustion of the organic moieties, and do not end until 800°C, as demonstrated in 
a. The final products are not characterized. TGA curve of 2 shows similar thermal decomposition behaviors. The TGA curve exhibits an initial weight loss of 11.8% from 30 to 160°C for 2 (calcd: 10.9%) ().

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Reversible desorption–adsorption behavior of lattice water</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Interestingly, the reversible desorption–adsorption characteristic of lattice water is significantly found in both <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Herein, only the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> will be served as a concrete example to be described in detail. The as-synthesized compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was heated at 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h in air, and a dehydrated sample was obtained, the predictable chemical composition is [Y(L)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]. as revealed by the elemental analysis experiment (Anal. Calcd: C, 26.33; H, 3.22; N, 24.57%; Found: C, 26.40; H, 3.17 N, 24.63%). The results of elemental analyses show that five lattice water molecules in the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are fully desorbed, but two coordination water molecules in the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> still maintained. This result is consistent with thermal analysis data as illustrated in b. However, the dehydrated example exhibits a white non-transparent crystal instead of a single crystal form (-2). Interestingly, the dehydrated example of [Y(L)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] can be restored to the single crystal form of [Y(L)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O again after being soaked in water for 2 days, as shown by the elemental analysis experiment (Anal. Calcd: C, 23.27; H, 4.14; N, 21.72%. Found: C, 23.23; H, 4.16; N, 21.67%). The prediction is further verified by the thermal analysis (c) and XRD (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>
-4d) legend. The rehydrated example exhibits the same characteristic diffraction peaks in XRD patterns (-4d) compared with that of the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (-4b). Furthermore, the similar crystallographic data of the restored sample based on the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are also obtained by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Hence, the desorption–adsorption characteristic of lattice water in the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a reversible process in our tests. Similar phenomenon is also observed in compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Reversible desorption–adsorption behavior of lattice water
Interestingly, the reversible desorption–adsorption characteristic of lattice water is significantly found in both 1 and 2. Herein, only the compound 1 will be served as a concrete example to be described in detail. The as-synthesized compound 1 was heated at 160°C for 12h in air, and a dehydrated sample was obtained, the predictable chemical composition is [Y(L)1.5(H2O)2]. as revealed by the elemental analysis experiment (Anal. Calcd: C, 26.33; H, 3.22; N, 24.57%; Found: C, 26.40; H, 3.17 N, 24.63%). The results of elemental analyses show that five lattice water molecules in the compound 1 are fully desorbed, but two coordination water molecules in the compound 1 still maintained. This result is consistent with thermal analysis data as illustrated in b. However, the dehydrated example exhibits a white non-transparent crystal instead of a single crystal form (-2). Interestingly, the dehydrated example of [Y(L)1.5(H2O)2] can be restored to the single crystal form of [Y(L)1.5(H2O)2]·5H2O again after being soaked in water for 2 days, as shown by the elemental analysis experiment (Anal. Calcd: C, 23.27; H, 4.14; N, 21.72%. Found: C, 23.23; H, 4.16; N, 21.67%). The prediction is further verified by the thermal analysis (c) and XRD (
-4d) legend. The rehydrated example exhibits the same characteristic diffraction peaks in XRD patterns (-4d) compared with that of the compound 1 (-4b). Furthermore, the similar crystallographic data of the restored sample based on the compound 1 are also obtained by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Hence, the desorption–adsorption characteristic of lattice water in the compound 1 is a reversible process in our tests. Similar phenomenon is also observed in compound 2 ().

. elements.clean_text:
The phenomenon can be explained, according to Kitagawa classification, the reversible desorption–adsorption behavior of lattice water may be attributed to the guest-induced crystal-to-crystal transformation in the framework of compounds 1 and 2
. Meantime, the 3-D framework in the compound has not been destroyed and the close-packing force is effective when the guest water molecules are removed, and the single crystal form of [Ln(L)1.5(H2O)2]·5H2O is restored again with the reintroduction of water molecules. It is not difficult to understand owing to hydrogen bond-regulated microporous nature within the compound structure . Recently, an analogue illustration based on complex [Tb2(BDOA)3(H2O)4]·6H2O is reported by Hong et al. , in which the crystal form of [Tb2(BDOA)3(H2O)4]·6H2O can be converted into the amorphous powder of [Tb2(BDOA)3(H2O)2] by heating at 120°C for 12h, and then the latter is restored to the crystalline form of [Tb2(BDOA)3(H2O)4]·6H2O after being soaked in water for 12h. However, two coordination water molecules in [Tb2(BDOA)3(H2O)4]·6H2O are simultaneously removed with the desorption of lattice water in the first dehydration stage, meanwhile, a low dehydrated temperature of 120°C is observed in the complex. As can be seen from the above results, the thermal stability based on the dehydration temperature of crystal water for [Tb2(BDOA)3(H2O)4]·6H2O is not very well as compared with that of the title two compounds. Furthermore, the rate of water content for 1 is about 13.2% (w/w) while the latter is about 12.3% (w/w). The above results imply that the title two compounds may be used for late-model desiccant/water absorbent as potential adsorption material.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Two novel 3D network lanthanide (III) complexes containing 2-fold interpenetration, {[<ce:italic>Ln</ce:italic>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>[<ce:italic>Ln</ce:italic>=Y(<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), Ce(<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>); L=1,2-bis[3-(1,2,4-triazolyl)-4-amino-5-carboxylmethylthio] ethane have been obtained. The reversible desorption–adsorption behavior of lattice water for the title compounds has been investigated. The results indicate that they may be good candidate as late-model desiccant/water absorbent in the field of adsorption material.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions
Two novel 3D network lanthanide (III) complexes containing 2-fold interpenetration, {[Ln(L)1.5(H2O)2]·5H2O}n[Ln=Y(1), Ce(2); L=1,2-bis[3-(1,2,4-triazolyl)-4-amino-5-carboxylmethylthio] ethane have been obtained. The reversible desorption–adsorption behavior of lattice water for the title compounds has been investigated. The results indicate that they may be good candidate as late-model desiccant/water absorbent in the field of adsorption material.
